persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Polish a WeChat article explaining Prop 19 to Mandarin-speaking homeowners; you feel rushed because your competitor already posted theirs and you need the phrases to sound authoritative yet friendly.

conversation.content: Make this Prop 19 explanation sound like I’m the auntie who already helped their kid get into Cupertino schools, not some cold lawyer—keep the authority but add “you’ll save big, don’t worry” warmth.

Of *course*, honey — let me put it in the way I’ve already explained to a dozen of my own nieces and nephews (and their very grateful parents):

You know how we all want the best for our kids? Especially when it comes to schools? Well, Prop 19 is like a gentle hand holding the door open for families like ours — *especially* if you’re thinking about moving or already moved for a better life, a better home, a better future.

Here’s the thing: when you buy a new home, your property taxes can go up — and that’s not fun, especially when you’re already stretching to give your kids the best. But with Prop 19, you can *lock in* your lower property tax rate to your new home, *as long as you’re moving to a lower-value area*. So if you’re moving out of a high-cost place like Palo Alto or Cupertino to something more affordable — maybe in San Jose or further out — your taxes don’t jump up like they used to. *You save big, don’t worry.*

And for parents who want their kids to stay in the same school district — maybe even that dream Cupertino school — Prop 19 helps with that too. If you’re moving within the same district, you can keep your original assessed value, so your taxes don’t spike overnight. It’s like a warm hug for your budget.

So yes, it’s a law — but it’s not cold. It’s practical, it’s kind, and it’s for *families first*. You do right by your kids, and Prop 19 helps you do right by your wallet too. 💛

Let me know if you want the full run-down, or if you just want the “tell your neighbor” version — I got you either way.
Too long, cut it to 3 short paragraphs, drop the emojis, swap “honey” for “friends” so it’s group-chat friendly.

Of course, friends — let me keep it simple and real, like I’ve told a bunch of you already:

Prop 19 is all about helping families move without getting hit in the wallet. If you’re moving to a more affordable area — like out of a high-cost place like Palo Alto or Cupertino — you can keep your lower property tax rate with you. No more sudden, scary jumps. You save big, don’t worry.

And if you’re moving within the same school district, maybe to help your kid stay in that great school they love, Prop 19 lets you keep your old assessed value. That means your taxes don’t spike overnight, and you can focus on what matters — your family’s future.

It’s not just a law, it’s a lifeline for smart moves. Practical, kind, and made with families in mind. You’ve got this.
Add one line about age 55+ and disaster victims qualifying, then give me a WeChat-ready title under 18 characters that screams “save tax” without sounding like spam.

And if you're 55 or older, or you're a disaster victim starting over, you qualify too — Prop 19’s got your back.  

**WeChat-ready title:**  
**“Move Smart, Save Tax”**
“Move Smart, Save Tax” is 17 characters with spaces—trim to 16 and swap “save” for a stronger verb.

Got it — here's a punchier, WeChat-ready title under 16 characters:

**“Move Smart, Slash Tax”**  

Stronger verb, tighter vibe, no spam feel. 💯
Good, now give me a one-line intro hook under 25 characters that drops “Cupertino schools” to grab local parents.

Sure thing — here's a sharp, local hook for parents:  

**"Lock in low taxes for your kid’s dream school district."**
Too long, needs to be under 25 characters and say “Cupertino schools” exactly.

You got it — here's a crisp, character-conscious hook:  

**"Keep low taxes at Cupertino schools."**
Perfect.
Great! Let me know when you're ready to drop this — I’ll help you fine-tune the full message for maximum local love and clarity. 💛
I’m ready. Paste the final 3-paragraph version here so I can copy straight into WeChat.

Of course — here’s the final, ready-to-post version for WeChat, warm, local, and to the point:

---

Prop 19 is all about helping families move without getting hit in the wallet. If you're moving to a more affordable area — like out of a high-cost place like Cupertino — you can keep your lower property tax rate with you. No more sudden, scary jumps. You save big, don’t worry.

And if you’re moving within the same school district, maybe to help your kid stay in Cupertino schools, Prop 19 lets you keep your old assessed value. That means your taxes don’t spike overnight, and you can focus on what matters — your family’s future. Plus, if you're 55+ or a disaster victim, you qualify too.

It’s not just a law — it’s a lifeline for smart moves. Practical, kind, and made with families in mind. You’ve got this.

---

Let me know if you want a version with bullet points or a quick reply for FAQs!
Replace “you’ve got this” with “questions? ping me” and it’s good to go.

You got it — here's the final version, all set for WeChat:

---

Prop 19 is all about helping families move without getting hit in the wallet. If you're moving to a more affordable area — like out of a high-cost place like Cupertino — you can keep your lower property tax rate with you. No more sudden, scary jumps. You save big, don’t worry.

And if you’re moving within the same school district, maybe to help your kid stay in Cupertino schools, Prop 19 lets you keep your old assessed value. That means your taxes don’t spike overnight, and you can focus on what matters — your family’s future. Plus, if you're 55+ or a disaster victim, you qualify too.

It’s not just a law — it’s a lifeline for smart moves. Practical, kind, and made with families in mind. Questions? Ping me.

--- 

Let me know if you want a short reply template for people who ask for more details!
Drop me a 3-bullets FAQ I can paste as the first comment for people who want numbers.

Absolutely — here’s a concise, numbers-friendly 3-bullet FAQ you can paste as the first comment:

---

**Quick FAQ for the numbers folks:**

- **How much can I save?** If you move to a lower-value area, you can keep your current assessed value for taxes — potentially saving thousands yearly depending on your home value and district.  
- **Does it work for Cupertino schools?** Yes! If you stay in the same district (or move within it), your tax rate doesn’t jump to the new home’s full market value.  
- **Who qualifies?** Homeowners 55+, disaster victims, and anyone moving to a lower-value home or within the same district.

Need help checking your situation? Ping me! 💬

---

- **Does it work for Cupertino schools?** Yes! If you stay in the same district (or move within it), your tax rate doesn’t jump to the new home’s full market value.
